reviewText:
Like many people, started playing this back in the early Xbox 360 days, and I find it still holds up as being an extremely enjoyable arcade game, and if you at all enjoy these types of games, I really can't recommend this enough.  Geometry Wars feels like an homage or love letter to classic games like Defender, Space Invaders, and Asteroid.

The gameplay is extremely fun and finds the right balance of casual gameplay and simultaneously being very challenging while even approaching unforgiving/punishing in how hard it can be.  It's hard to explain the experience of how playing this game can be relaxing and leasurely and, in the same session, become intense and anxiety-provoking, causing a release of adreniline in the player.  It's also difficult to explain how rewarding it is to feel yourself naturally responding to the challenges the game throws at you and finding yourself handling situations and reacting differently, getting through a point in the game that used to have you stuck.  The game itself is very well made and has a great feel to it, and the graphics are beautiful.

My only two minor quibbles with the Steam release are lack of an online Leaderboard (probably has something to do with Activision getting shutdown and that they just used Xbox Live's leaderboard functionality before) and that the Steam release doesn't have any of the unlockable achievements the Xbox 360 version had (how hard would it have been to include those?).

I payed $1.99 for this on Steam and would have actually paid more.  Again, I can't recommend it enough for a modern take on classic Arcade gameplay.

Quick Breakdown: A fun arcade twin stick shooter. It’s a good game, but the newer Geometry Wars 3 has all the features of this game as bonus content.
Length: 1+ hour
Genre: Arcade, Twin Stick Shooter
Score: 6.5/10
Note: As I mentioned in the Quick Breakdown section, if you purchase  Geometry Wars 3: Dimensions Evolved, it includes a classic mode which is the same content of this game. So even though I’m giving this game a positive review, I recommend against buying it, and instead purchasing Geometry Wars 3, which is well worth buying for its own game as well.

Full Review: Geometry Wars: Retro Evolved is a pretty simple, but addicting game. You play as a small ship on a flat board that must fend of waves of different geometric enemies. There are about half a dozen or so different shapes, and each shape behaves in a different manner. Some enemies will sit in place on the map, others move about aimlessly, and some chase after you.

Before I talk about the gameplay, I just want to note that this game is nigh unplayable without a controller. When I refer to the controls in this review, it will be in reference to when using an actual controller.

That said, the controls are very simple as well. You use one joystick to move about the map, and the other to shoot in any direction, hence why it’s a twin stick shooter. You can also use one of the shoulder buttons to activate a bomb, which will wipe out all enemies on the map. You begin the game with 3 bombs and 3 lives, though you can acquire more by scoring points, which is done simply by killing enemies.

The aim of the game is simply to rack up as high of a score as you can before you bite the dust for the final time. A game won’t last very long, only a few minutes, but you’ll get enough reply out of it to get at least an hour’s worth of gameplay out of it.

It’s a fun game, but you’re better off just buying Geometry Wars 3: Dimensions Evolved, since it includes the content of this game a lot more. Still, it’s only a few bucks if you’re like me and insist on getting it anyway.
